questions.question: What region is pain present in?
Do you have a recent history of fall or trauma in the affected region?
How did the pain begin?
Do you experience tingling or abnormal sensations?
Do you have swelling in the area of complaint?
Did you notice any unusual movement in the area of complaint?
What aggravates this pain?
Do you feel pain when you try to raise your arm?
Is there tenderness around the shoulder region or on palpating root of the neck?
Is your sleep affected by pain?
Is shoulder alignment proper?
Is bruising and swelling present?
Is patient adopting a pain avoidance posture by clasping hands together?
Is there a bump or obvious deformity around the clavicle?

Does pain reduce with rest OR anti-inflammatory use?

effects.notes: Biccipital tendinitis can co-exist with other rotator cuff pathologies

questions.question: Are you above 45yrs of age?
Do you have a previous history of sprain or a jerking movement at the shoulder?

answers.value: Check if the patient can complete a full abduction of the arm.
If pt, cannot initiate arm ABduction – full tear
If active ABduction is possible – partial tear.
Pain is aggraavated between the range of 60 - 120 deg
Pain is alleviated IF shoulder is laterally rotated on ABduction
Positive sign, Affected side is weaker than the unaffected side.
Positive sign suggests tear in the supraspinatus
Lack of power on one side indicates weakness of the infraspinatus muscle
If test is done with arm in 90 deg elevation

tests.name: Clinical Assessment
tests.procedure: Physical examination and clinical assessment based on presenting symptoms

questions.question: What is the pain type?
How did the pain begin?
Did the pain increase drastically within a few hours?

answers.value: Do you experience pain more at night

questions.question: Can you perform the movements around the shoulder joint?
Does the pain subside after a few days and the shoulder is restored to normal functioning?

tests.name: Check X-ray to rule asymptomatic calcification
Lesions of the Biceps Tendon (Confirmation)
Biccipital Tendinitis as above
Speed Test
tests.procedure: Place pt’s arm in shoulder flexion, forearm supination and elbow extension. The examiner then applies pressure to the arm as downward action.

tests.name: A positive sign, pain in the bicipital grove is replicable
Yergasom’s test
tests.procedure: Pt places the forearm in the supine position, and the examiner applies resistance against supination.

tests.name: A positive sign, this replicates the pain in the bicipital group tenderness.
Rupture of the Biceps Tendon (Confirmation)
Age (over 50yrs)
Ask pt to lift or offer resistance to biceps contraction
Is a prominent lump is seen in lower arm
The upper arm becomes painful and bruised
Hypertrophy and intra-articular entrapment (the hourglass biceps)
Ask patient to elevate the shoulder
SLAP LESION (Confirmation)
Ask the patient to throw to reach a far distance where above shoulder movement is indicated.
Patient is unable to
Patient is able to
Patient is able to (with pain involvement)

Instruct the patient to flex the arm up to 90 deg with the elbow in full extension.Then ask pt to adduct arm 10-15 deg medial to sagittal plane. Arm is maximally internally rotated and examiner applies downward pressure while patient is asked to resist.  Procedure is then repeated in supination
Positive
tests.procedure: Pain is elicited by the first manoeuvre, and is reduced or eliminated by the second.

tests.name: ADHESIVE CAPSULITIS (Frozen Shoulder Syndrome)
Yes (Check for adhesive capsulitis– early phase. Carry out active and passive movements)
Currently, do you find it difficult to turn your shoulder in (Internal rotation)
tests.procedure: or move your arms towards your body/chest (Adduction)

tests.name: Yes (Check for adhesive capsulitis – freezing phase)
Yes (Traumatic Adhesive Capsulitis)
No (Non-traumatic Adhesive Capsulitis)
Test for Adhesive Capsulitis
Clinical Observation
tests.procedure: Check if the Active range of motion and passive range of motion is full across shoulder joints

tests.name: Active and Passive range of motion is limited in Adhesive Capsulitis
Rule out other causes of stiffness with imaging
Special Test for Biccipital Tendinitis
Is buckling of tendon present?
Do you feel pain on shoulder elevation?
Can the patient elevate the arm up till the end of the range?
Did you have any history of fall or trauma with hand stretched out?
Did you have any history of loading the shoulder region with weight?
Do you feel a ‘painful click’ when you lift your arm above shoulder height?
Do you feel weakness in your arm when doing activities above shoulder height?
Special Test for SLAP (O’Brien’s test)
At the early phase of this pain, did you find it difficult to turn your shoulder out (External rotation)
tests.procedure: and/or take your arm away from your body (abduction)?

tests.name: Do you find it easier to move your shoulder backwards (extension)
Do you experience progressive stiffness in your shoulder?
Is the pain worse at night?
Have you had any of the following conditions before
tests.procedure: Diabetes, Dupuytren’s, hyperlipidemia, hyperthyroidism, cardiac disease, hemiplegia?

tests.name: Have you undergone a neurosurgical procedure before?
Previous history of fall or trauma to affected side?

questions.question: Have you had a previous history of a shoulder dislocation?
Did the first episode occur with a pull on an abducted, laterally rotated-extended arm?
Do you experience a catching sensation followed by numbness or weakness (Dead-arm syndrome) when making overhead arm movements?

rule_out: rotator cuff disorder and cervical radiculitis

tests.name: Apprehension Test

Patient is in sitting or lying position, the examiner lifts the arn gently into ABduction, external rotation and then extension. Test is positive if Pt senses that humeral head is about to slip out anteriorly and body stiffens in apprehension.
The test is repeated with the anterior part of shoulder protected.
Fulcrum’s Test

Pt lies supine, arm ABducted up to 90 deg. The examiner places their hands over the shoulder to set the fulcrum base. The humeral head is levered forward by extending and externally rotating arm. The patient immediately becomes apprehensive.
Drawer’s Test
Patient lies supine , scapula is stabilised with one hand while the upper arm is grasped firmly with the other, and manoeuvring is done forward and backward (like a drawer)
tests.procedure: . The drawer’s test is positive if instability is marked.

questions.question: Do you have a history of generalised Rheumatoid Arthritis?
Do you experience pain and swelling in both shoulder joints?
Do you smoke?
Do you have episodes of fever that resolve spontaneously?
Is swelling present anteriorly and superiorly to the shoulder?
Is swelling present in the axilla?
Do you experience increasing limitations in performing self-care (styling hair, dressing, shaving)?

tests.name: Radiographic confirmation – check for periarticular erosions, subchondral sclerosis, and resorption.

questions.question: Have you had a previous history of injury, shoulder dislocation, or painful arc syndrome?
Do you feel the pain more at night?
Is your shoulder movement restricted across ALL joint motions?

rule_out: Adhesive Capsulitis. Extension is free in Adhesive Capsulitis

questions.question: Do you experience early morning stiffness?
If yes, does the stiffness wane within 30 minutes of waking?

tests.name: Radiographic confirmation – check for distortion of the joint, subchondral sclerosis, osteophyte formation, and narrowing of articular space.
